title: 105_s619
content: The Act titled "Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Act of 1997" defines key terms. The Act "Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Act of 1997" defines key terms related to the Chesapeake Bay, including Chesapeake Bay Gateways sites, Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Network, Chesapeake Bay Watershed, Chesapeake Bay Watertrails, and the Secretary of the Interior. Congress recognizes the Chesapeake Bay as a national treasure with unique natural and cultural resources. There is a need to study the connection between human settlements in the watershed and the natural resources they depend on. The Secretary has a responsibility to support efforts to increase public awareness of the Chesapeake Bay Program. The Chesapeake Bay is recognized as a national treasure with unique resources. Efforts are being made to increase public awareness, conserve regional resources, and connect them with conservation and education initiatives in the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. The Act aims to increase public access and education about the Chesapeake Bay, provide assistance for conserving natural and cultural resources, and connect national parks and historic sites into a network of Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails. The Secretary will provide technical and financial assistance to identify, conserve, restore, and interpret natural, recreational, historical, and cultural resources within the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. This includes enhancing public education and access to the Chesapeake Bay through Gateways sites, linking sites with trails and scenic byways, and developing water routes and connections within the watershed. The Chesapeake Bay Gateways and Watertrails Network aims to preserve and interpret resources in the watershed, including State or Federal parks, historic seaports, cultural sites, and public access sites selected by the Secretary. The Chesapeake Bay Gateways Grants Assistance Program is established under SEC. 6. The Secretary establishes the Chesapeake Bay Gateways Grants Assistance Program to aid in conserving, restoring, and interpreting resources within the Chesapeake Bay Watershed. Eligibility, prioritization, and review criteria for grants will be developed. Grants will cover up to 50% of project costs, with non-Federal sources providing the rest, and no more than 10% of costs used for administrative expenses.
